Title: A Randomised Controlled Trial of a Decision Aid for Smoking Cessation in Elective Surgery Patients

Background: Decision aids can enhance patient involvement in healthcare decision-making. This study aimed to evaluate a decision aid for discussing smoking behavior change options before and after elective surgery.

Methods: A randomised, two-group pilot study was conducted in a preoperative clinic. Participants were smokers preparing for elective surgery. The decision aid, consisting of three laminated cards, was designed to facilitate discussions on continuing smoking, temporary abstinence, or quitting smoking. The primary outcome was decisional quality, measured using the Decisional Conflict and OPTION scales. Randomisation was performed at the patient level, with allocation concealment ensured. Neither patients nor clinicians were blinded.

Results: A total of 130 patients were randomised: 65 to the decision aid group and 65 to usual care. The decision aid significantly improved decisional quality (Cohen’s d = 0.76) and patient involvement (Cohen’s d = 1.20) compared to usual care (p < 0.05). However, it did not affect perioperative smoking behavior. No adverse events were reported.

Interpretation: The decision aid improved decisional quality and patient involvement but did not change smoking behavior. Further research is needed to explore additional strategies for behavior change.
